Award.AwardTitle: SBIR Phase I: Bridging the Education Gap Between Block-Based Programs and Cryptic C++ Code with an Internet of Things Based Interactive Code Development and Debug Platform
Award.AbstractNarration:
This SBIR Phase I project will develop a low cost educational platform which provides students a gateway to understanding and writing software code in modern real-world programming languages. The research addresses a pressing need in the K-12 setting to engage both teachers and students in Coding as a Literacy. Current approaches to teaching computer science and programming principles in K-12 often fail to bridge the gap between block-based graphical representations and text-based programming languages. Strong growth in Maker Spaces within school classrooms and libraries has led to a proliferation of Maker-oriented products in the K-12 setting, but teachers and students alike struggle to understand the software coding required to make meaningful use of them. The project embraces the Maker spirit with an expandable robotics platform that provides fertile ground for lesson development, paired with software that enables step-by-step execution of the student's code over a wireless connection. The commercialization of this technology will augment the effectiveness of STEM initiatives underway in the nation?s schools, keep students engaged in more advanced computer programming as they transition into middle and high school levels, boost the enrollment in technical disciplines at the University level, and ultimately increase the technology-related global competitiveness of the national workforce.

The goal of this project is to overcome current limitations in microcontroller-based software development, with specific focus on the enablement of interactive debugging capabilities without the use of "target monitor" hardware external to the microcontroller itself. The project includes both software and hardware development efforts, as the research is directed at enabling a highly integrated system through the use of state-of-the-art silicon technology designed for Internet of Things (IoT) applications. The advent of these System on Chip (SoC) integrated circuits brings the potential for a radically lower cost, IP-connected educational technology platform. The hardware aspect of the project will include development of a printed circuit board (PCB) assembly leveraging a wireless SoC to provide a Wi-Fi connected robotic computing platform with an expandable circuit interface and a complement of built-in peripherals designed for educational applications. The software will provide a web-based user interface seamlessly integrated with the hardware platform to enable a level of interactive coding not previously seen on a wireless SoC. The commercialized product resulting from this project will leverage this interactive debugging user experience to teach real-world programming language development skills.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The aim of this research was to develop an educational technology platform that enables teachers with no prior computer science (CS) training to successfully teach text-based coding in the K-12 setting. At the outset we began testing the hypothesis that the use of Internet of Things microcontroller technology, combined with an innovative approach to teaching text-based code through the use of software debugging tools, would provide significant advantages to student engagement and teacher acceptance.

During the first few months of research we conducted dozens of face-to-face interviews with K-12 teachers who were charged with introducing students to CS topics, and found that most of them had little or no formal CS training. By and large, we found that teachers (even at the secondary level) were not comfortable with text-based programming. This appears to be a primary driver for the prevalence of the block-based approaches that are often used even at the middle and high-school levels. However, while many educators admitted to being intimidated by text-based programming, they also confirmed that the toy-like nature of block-based coding instruction turns some students off. It was noted that many students, including girls in particular, lose interest in toys and games by around the 7th grade. On the contrary, real-world programming languages offer meaningful connection to something grown-up. Through this connection, students are able to earn a sense of accomplishment, and feel empowered to make an impact on the world. Our hypothesis regarding the engagement factor of physical computing devices was largely confirmed based on these interviews, but the prospect of introducing text-based coding appeared to be more challenging than expected.

Early in the research, we decided to adopt an existing hardware platform (the micro:bit), in lieu of developing a proprietary system, so that R&D efforts could be focused on the software development necessary to enable a breakthrough level of usability and guidance in text-based programming. Our intensive software research bore fruit in the form of numerous first of a kind products, including the first embedded python debugger implementation, the first commercial WebUSB IDE, and the first commercial python parser capable of running in-browser on Chromebooks.

The project followed an iterative lean startup model, designed to minimize risk with fast feedback cycles that validated market assumptions while achieving technical milestones. Personalized training and professional development was provided directly to a significant number of K-12 teachers in 14 school districts comprising the Beta Testing cohort. From the outset we understood that a major barrier to teaching CS in K-12 schools was lack of teacher training. This was confirmed emphatically by teachers and administrators during our customer discovery process, beta testing, and follow-on commercialization efforts.

The technology innovation focus of this project inherently addresses the Professional Development (PD) challenge through a guided, personalized learning approach. One of the major selling points of the coding education platform developed in Phase I, when compared with other approaches to text-based coding instruction, is the reduced need for extensive teacher training. The debugging and error detection facilities integrated within the coding curriculum serve to train the teachers as well as the students. To a large degree, professional development is built into the platform. Moreover, this form of PD is highly scalable, as it minimizes costs, travel expenses, and time investment for teachers and schools. It also reduces the need for highly-qualified CS instructors, who are in short supply, to conduct personalized training.

Prior to the conclusion of this Phase I project, the initial CodeSpace product was launched into the market in the form of cloud-based software coupled with hardware-based kits. Market validation and product feature iteration are ongoing, and thousands of students across the nation are already benefiting from this research. Follow-on research and development will build on this success to introduce millions more students to CS.
